source_books: Science and Practice of Flexibility (3rd Ed.)
evidence_base: Movement assessment and corrective exercise research

exercises.scientific_explanation: The couch stretch targets the psoas major and rectus femoris in their lengthened position, addressing the most common restriction in modern athletes. Research shows 20-25% improvements in hip extension ROM after 4 weeks. The stretch position replicates functional demands of running and jumping while providing sustained tissue adaptation stimulus.
research_citations: Starrett & Cordoza (2013): Hip flexor mobility interventions
Page et al. (2010): Hip flexibility assessment
exercises.form_cue: Back foot on couch, front leg in lunge, drive hips forward and down
exercises.common_mistake: Compensating with lumbar extension instead of achieving true hip extension

exercises.scientific_explanation: The 90/90 position addresses both hip internal and external rotation simultaneously, targeting the deep hip rotators including piriformis and deep six. Research demonstrates 15-20° improvements in hip rotation ROM bilaterally. The position is particularly effective for athletes with hip impingement or reduced rotational capacity.
research_citations: Lewis et al. (2018): Hip rotation mobility interventions
Prather et al. (2019): Deep hip rotator function
exercises.form_cue: Both legs at 90 degrees, lean forward over front leg then rotate to back leg
exercises.common_mistake: Using spine rotation instead of hip rotation reduces effectiveness

exercises.scientific_explanation: The cat-cow movement pattern promotes segmental spinal mobility through controlled flexion and extension. Research shows improvements in thoracic extension ROM of 8-12° after 4-week interventions. The quadruped position provides spinal unloading while allowing active range of motion development.
research_citations: Kuo et al. (2009): Thoracic mobility interventions
O'Sullivan et al. (2006): Spinal movement training
exercises.form_cue: Move slowly vertebra by vertebra, initiate movement from pelvis
exercises.common_mistake: Moving too quickly or only at cervical and lumbar regions

exercises.scientific_explanation: Band shoulder dislocations improve shoulder girdle mobility through controlled circumduction movement. Research demonstrates 15-18% increases in shoulder flexion and extension ROM. The exercise promotes proper scapulohumeral rhythm and is essential for overhead athletes and desk workers with forward head posture.
research_citations: McClure et al. (2007): Shoulder mobility interventions
Lewis et al. (2005): Scapular muscle function
exercises.form_cue: Wide grip, slow controlled circles, keep arms straight throughout
exercises.common_mistake: Using momentum or grip too narrow reduces mobility benefits

exercises.scientific_explanation: Wall ankle stretching targets gastrocnemius and soleus while providing quantifiable ROM assessment. Research shows ankle dorsiflexion <10° increases injury risk by 40% in runners. The weight-bearing position replicates functional demands while providing sustained stretch stimulus for tissue adaptation.
research_citations: Hoch & McKeon (2011): Ankle mobility and injury risk
Macrum et al. (2012): Ankle dorsiflexion assessment
exercises.form_cue: Keep heel down, lean into wall until stretch felt in calf, hold knee straight
exercises.common_mistake: Lifting heel or allowing foot pronation reduces stretch effectiveness

exercises.scientific_explanation: The pigeon pose provides sustained stretch to the hip external rotators and posterior hip capsule. Research demonstrates 12-18% improvements in hip internal rotation after 6-week interventions. The position is particularly effective for addressing piriformis syndrome and deep hip tightness common in runners and cyclists.
research_citations: Lewis & Sahrmann (2006): Hip rotation and pain
Gajdosik et al. (2007): Passive hip rotation ROM
exercises.form_cue: Front leg at 90 degrees, back leg straight, sink hips toward ground
exercises.common_mistake: Not squaring hips or forcing the stretch beyond tissue tolerance
